title: Hiroshi Ochiai
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Ochiai was born in <a href="Saitama%20%28city%29">Saitama</a> on 28 February 1946. After graduating from high school, he joined <a href="Hokkaido%20Consadole%20Sapporo">Toshiba</a> in 1964. He played at offensive position. In 1966, he moved to his local club <a href="Urawa%20Reds">Mitsubishi Motors</a> played in <a href="Japan%20Soccer%20League">Japan Soccer League</a> (JSL). He played in all 260 matches in the league until 1981. In 1969, he became a top scorer and the club won the champions at <a href="1969%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">JSL</a> first time. In the 1970s he was converted to defensive position. In 1973, the club won <a href="1973%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">JSL</a> and <a href="1973%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a>. In 1978, the club won all three major title in Japan; <a href="1978%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">JSL</a>, <a href="1978%20JSL%20Cup">JSL Cup</a>, <a href="1978%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> and he was selected Japanese Footballer of the Year awards. He retired in 1984. He played 267 games and scored 56 goals in the league. This 267 games is the second record in JSL after <a href="Yoshikazu%20Nagai">Yoshikazu Nagai</a> (272 games). He was selected Best Eleven 10 times included for 9 years in a row (<a href="1973%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1973</a>-<a href="1981%20Japan%20Soccer%20League">1981</a>). The club won the league champions 2 times, <a href="JSL%20Cup">JSL Cup</a> 2 times and <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> 4 times.
National team career.
In September 1974, Ochiai was selected <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> for <a href="Football%20at%20the%201974%20Asian%20Games">1974 Asian Games</a>. At this competition, on 7 September, he debuted against <a href="Israel%20national%20football%20team">Israel</a>. After his debut, he played in most games included <a href="Football%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20qualification">1976 Summer Olympics qualification</a>, <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%20and%20OFC%29">1978 World Cup qualification</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201978%20Asian%20Games">1978 Asian Games</a>. In 1980, <a href="Football%20at%20the%201980%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20qualification">1980 Summer Olympics qualification</a> was his last game for Japan. He played 63 games and scored 9 goals for Japan until 1980.
Coaching career.
After retirement, in 1988, Ochiai became coach for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> under manager <a href="Kenzo%20Yokoyama">Kenzo Yokoyama</a> was team mate at <a href="Urawa%20Reds">Mitsubishi Motors</a>. In 1992, Ochiai became a coach for <a href="Urawa%20Reds">Urawa Reds</a> (former "Mitsubishi Motors") under manager <a href="Takaji%20Mori">Takaji Mori</a>.
In 2010, Ochiai was selected <a href="Japan%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Japan Football Hall of Fame</a>.
